results.title: Jason and the Argonauts [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Don Chaffey, Charles H. Schneer and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Stemming from Greek mythology, this is the tale of the voyages of the intrepid Jason and his Argonauts on a quest to find the legendary Golden Fleece. He and his crew must brave all manner of dangers and face a host of terrifying foes, including the seven-headed Hydra, fighting skeletons, bloodthirsty Harpies and the invincible colossus Talos. It is also a tale of love, as the beautiful Medea risks everything for Jason and his quest. For its time, the special effects of Ray Harryhausen were given accolades by the critics. Stars Todd Armstrong as Jason and Nancy Kovack as Medea.

constellations_other.name: Sublime light and special effects
constellations_other.description: Explore 19th-century artist John Martin’s surprising influence on science fiction and fantasy films of the 20th century, from Jason and the Argonauts to the Lord of the Rings and the Evil Dead franchises.

results.title: Loser [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Amy Heckerling, Twink Caplan and Columbia Pictures Industries
results.brief_description: Fresh from the success of “Clueless”, Amy Heckerling (Fast times at Ridgemont High) dived into the life of the nerd in “Loser.” Jason Biggs (American Pie) is Paul Tanneck, a good-natured Mid Western teenager who wins a university scholarship and moves to New York City. Naively confident in his signature ear flap hat, Paul is thrust into campus life with 3 despicable drug addicted and brattish room mates who have nothing but contempt for him but are not adverse to asking favours when it suits them. He meets a soul mate in Literature class in Dora Diamond (Mena Suvari), a fellow outsider who appears to be operating on his wavelength. Following an alcohol drenched party hosted by his now ex-room mates at his new abode, Paul discovers Dora unconscious in the bathroom and takes her to the hospital. The two spend a few nights together while Dora recovers from having her stomach pumped and the two prove to be compatible. When Paul discovers Dora is having an affair with Literature’s Professor Alcott (Greg Kinnear), he withdraws his attentions from her even though he can see through the philandering professor that Dora blithely dotes on. “Loser” is populated with caricatured college stereotypes and behaviour that borders on depressing rather than amusing, however the outcome is transparent, so you know the character flogging will abate.

results.title: Body double [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Brian De Palma and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Brian De Palma’s “Body double” - like most of his body of work - are genre exercises which borrow and pay homage to the films of Alfred Hitchcock. The Hitchcock template for this film is “Rear window” and “Vertigo”, perversely reworked into a lurid, violent thriller which proudly wears all it’s sleazy excesses on its sleeve. Craig Wassen plays Jake, a down on his luck actor who has just been fired from a shlock Z-grade vampire film due to his claustrophobia, a problem considering he spends several scenes inside a coffin. Dumped by his girlfriend and evicted from his flat, Jake finds himself homeless until a fellow actor (Gregg Henry) suggests he temporarily house-sit a rich record producer’s house. One of the perks of house-sitting he soon discovers is the sexy neighbour (Deborah Shelton) across the road who loves to undress in front of her window. Soon Jake finds himself obsessively spying on his mysterious neighbour as he inadvertently becomes embroiled in a nasty murder plot. Cast includes Melanie Griffith, Guy Boyd, Dennis Franz.

results.title: The Day of the jackal [DVD]
results.creator_credit: John Woolf, Fred Zimmerman, Universal Productions and Warwick Films
results.brief_description: Based on the best seller by Frederick Forsyth, “The Day of the jackal” is a taut and colourful suspense thriller about the attempt by the right wing OAS to assassinate General De Gaulle. Edward Fox portrays the ruthless, anonymous assassin hired by OAS Chief Colonel Rodin, played by Eric Porter. The cold precision of his preparations is juxtaposed with the plodding efforts of the French authorities to uncover the plot.

results.title: I Still know what you did last summer
results.creator_credit: Danny Cannon, Neal H. Moritz and Global Entertainment Productions
results.brief_description: Producer of “I know what you did last summer” Neal H. Moritz commented that “I Know” was positioned perfectly with the success of “Scream”, “Party of five” and “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.” Its sequel, “I still know what you did last summer,” without such support in its marketing campaign, was left to prove itself in a sea of teen horror films, all trailing in the wake of “Scream.” “I Still know” reunites us with our heroine, Julie James (Jennifer Love Hewitt), at university, far away from Southport where the horrors of last summer (and the summer before that), took place. The nightmares of the meat-hook-wielding fisherman are preventing Julie from putting the brutal murder of her best friend, Helen (Sarah Michelle Gellar), behind her. Luckily, Julie has made a new best friend, Karla (Brandy), who has won a trip to the Bahamas and convinces Julie to go with her and some other friends. They arrive only to discover that it’s the off-peak season and, with the exception of ‘marginally trained off-season staff’, they are alone on the island. Julie’s nightmares become a reality upon discovering the fisherman is on the island seeking his revenge. Julie is forced to fess up to her friends about her tormented past as they struggle for their lives knowing they are caught in total isolation. Refreshingly, “I Still know” has subscribed to the new paradigm of teen horror, whereby the protagonist teen character is given personality and a surname. With a supporting cast that is less disposable than the teenager characters of slasher films of the past, “I Still know” is more suspenseful and more frightening, and a horror film that can stand on its own merit. Cast includes: Jennifer Love Hewitt, Brandy, Freddy Prinze Jr., Mekhi Phifer, Muse Watson.

results.title: Toy story 2 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: John Lasseter, Ash Brannon, Karen Robert Jackson, Walt Disney Productions and Pixar Animation Studios
results.brief_description: Sequel to Disney’s 1995 hit film “Toy story.” Woody and Buzz are still competing to be the number one toy in Andy’s room. When Andy goes to summer camp the toys have their lives thrown into chaos when Woody is ‘toynapped’ by a nasty toy collector, and ends up in a museum. Buzz Lightyear and the rest of the toys set out on a rescue mission to save their friend from becoming an exhibit. But does Woody want to leave the quiet and peaceful life he has at the museum? Featuring voices by Tom Hanks, Tim Allen and Joan Cusack.

results.title: The Secret of Nimh 2: Timmy to the rescue
results.creator_credit: Dick Sebast, Jonathan Dern, Paul Sabella and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Jonathan Brisby, the bravest of all rats died in saving his fellow creatures from the evil clutches of NIMH. Once escaped, the rats made a home for themselves in Thorn Valley. It was predicted that one day the forces of NIMH would rise again and the son of Jonathan Brisby would save them; the destiny of rats lies with Timmy Brisby. Feeling the pressure to be the hero his father was, Timmy begins his journey with Jeremy the crow where he is placed under the tutelage of Mr Ages and fellow elders who equip him with the tools to face his destiny. A female rat called Jenny makes it to the village and implores them to return to NIMH with her and save the rats from the evil Doctor Valentine. The council decides against helping her however, and when Timmy discovers elder brother Martin is a prisoner at NIMH, he and Jenny decide to save the rats themselves. Made for television 16 years after the original and features musical numbers. Features the voices of Dom DeLuise, Eric Idle, Ralph Macchio, William H. Macy and Hynden Walch. Narrated by Peter MacNicoll.

results.title: The Secret of Nimh [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Don Bluth, Gary Goldman and Aurora
results.brief_description: The story of timid Mrs Brisby, a widowed field mouse who must summon the courage to defy man, beast and nature against the imminent destruction of her home before Farmer Fitzgibbon’s spring plowing. With the help of love-sick Jeremy the crow and the mysterious rats of NIMH (super intelligent creatures residing in the farmer’s rosebush), she finds the strength to overcome the obstacles that threaten her family. Based on the story by Robert C. O’Brien.

results.title: Gosford Park
results.creator_credit: Robert Altman, David Levy, Bob Balaban, Sandcastle 5 Productions, Zestwick Limited, Film Council and Capitol Films
results.brief_description: November 1932 - Gosford Park is the magnificent Estate of the unhappily married Sir William Cordle and Lady Sylvia. Immersed in an upper-class world of frippery, fine manners and nasty natures, various friends and associates gather for a weekend shooting party; when murder occurs, suspicious ulterior motives are revealed. But this narrative, largely related from the perspective of the servants, is less of a mystery than it is a comedy centering on the politics and mores of aristocratic society, the ‘upstairs’ shenanigans of which are mirrored by the equally fascinating world of footmen, butlers, valets, maids and cooks, who vehemently adhere to the below stairs strictures. With labyrinthine systems of etiquette and appropriate behaviours, these ‘downstairs’ caretakers are bland observers of their employers’ lives, who thrive on gossip and rumour, feeding off lascivious details and intricacies, whilst observing the treachery and mixed fortunes of their masters’ lives. Presenting over a score of well-defined players, it is a testament to Altman’s skill that none are mere ciphers, but rather sustain complex characterisations, creating a fascinating tableau of class politics, societal mores, perfidious interpersonal relationships and a cohesive panorama of human behaviour. Stellar cast includes: Eileen Atkins, Bob Balaban, Alan Bates, Charles Dance, Stephen Fry, Michael Gambon, Richard E. Grant, Tom Hollander, Derek Jacobi, Kelly Macdonald, Helen Mirren, Jeremy Northam, Clive Owen, Ryan Phillippe, Maggie Smith, Kristin Scott Thomas, Emily Watson and James Wilby.

Presenting over a score of well-defined players, it is a testament to Altman’s skill that none are mere ciphers, but rather sustain complex characterisations, creating a fascinating tableau of class politics, societal mores, perfidious interpersonal relationships and a cohesive panorama of human behaviour. Stellar cast includes: Eileen Atkins, Bob Balaban, Alan Bates, Charles Dance, Stephen Fry, Michael Gambon, Richard E. Grant, Tom Hollander, Derek Jacobi, Kelly Macdonald, Helen Mirren, Jeremy Northam, Clive Owen, Ryan Phillippe, Maggie Smith, Kristin Scott Thomas, Emily Watson and James Wilby.

results.title: Tigerland [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Joel Schumacher, Arnon Milchan, Steven Haft, Beau Flynn, Regency Enterprises, New Regency Pictures, Kirch Media and Haft Entertainment
results.brief_description: Tigerland is the name of a military base in the United States used for the training of recruits before they are to be sent to fight in the war in Vietnam. The film follows the recruits as they are increasingly pushed to the edge of their physical and mental capabilities by a dehumanising military regime convinced that only by brutalising the men will they be able to sufficiently face the terrors of the war ahead. Starring Colin Farrell as Roland Bozz, a young man whose independent spirit and questioning mind puts him immediately at odds with authority, “Tigerland” is a punishing but compelling view of army life. The actual war is in the background. It is as a study of masculinity, repressed sexuality and violence that the film is most effective. Usually known for bloated big-budget action films, director Schumacher has instead, in “Tigerland”, utilised hand-held camerawork, minimal special effects and a concentration on the performances of the actors to achieve his effects. As a late addition to the genre of Vietnam war film, “Tigerland” lacks the immediacy and hallucinatory contradictions of films such as “Apocalypse Now” or “The Deerhunter”: in many ways, for all its kinetic editing and camerawork, it is a traditional genre film. Nevertheless, the performances and the energetic direction ensures that it is both exciting and confronting.
